Hey,

Why it is that when NEAT (or maybe just sharpNEAT, what I'm looking at) runs networks, the input neurons' signals don't get changed even though there are connections to them? Unlike the other neurons, the input neurons are constantly firing, their signals don't reset to 0 after they fire.

This makes the connections to the input neurons useless, and also, the network is forced to be re-inundated with input signals during every step. I guess this is OK because if the network didn't want to keep getting signals, it could somehow trigger another recurrent neuron whose connection weights exactly cancels out ALL the input neuron's outgoing connection weights--but this is a complicated overhead to evolve. Whereas, if we treated input neurons like other neurons, to evolve the same constant-firing behavior, the network would only have to evolve a single recurrent neuron that the input neuron itself connects to. This recurrent neuron, created only if it is evolutionarily advantageous, will then constantly fire.

A side question is that if I save a population in SharpNEAT as an XML file, is some information lost? Whenever I reload a population from file, it's not as fit as when it left off.

Thanks,
Richard
